title: R package for mapping UK geographies
text: Super Output Areas (SOAs) set geographical areas developed following 2001 census, initially facilitate calculation Indices Deprivation 2004. aim produce set areas consistent size, whose boundaries change (unlike electoral wards). aggregation adjacent Output Areas similar social characteristics. Lower Layer Super Output Areas (LSOAs) typically contain 4 6 OAs population around 1500. Middle Layer Super Output Areas (MSOAs) average population 7,200.

title: R package for mapping UK geographies
text: Electoral wards/divisions key building blocks UK administrative geography. spatial units used elect local government councillors metropolitan non-metropolitan districts, unitary authorities London boroughs England; unitary authorities Wales; council areas Scotland; district council areas Northern Ireland.

title: R package for mapping UK geographies
text: English local authority districts (LAD) (metropolitan non-metropolitan), London boroughs unitary authorities average around 23 electoral wards/divisions , Northern Irish district council areas around 22, Scottish council areas around 11 Welsh unitary authorities 40. Population counts can vary substantially, even within single LAD, national average 5,500. LA’s split Lower Tier Local Authorities (LTLA’s) Upper Tier Local Authorities (UTLA’s). difference two LTLA’s use district councils UTLA’s use county councils. ONS refers LTLA’s LAD’s, UTLA’s Counties Unitary Authorities.

title: Aggregate LSOAs'21 to LSOA'11 for Left Behind Areas - England and Wales — aggregate_lba_lsoas
text: Changes made England Wales 2011 LSOA codes 2021 reflect population household changes. Change codes: U = Unchanged - 31,810 LSOAs remained unchanged 2011 2021 S = Split - 834 LSOAs split 2011 2021 two M = Merged - 194 LSOAs merged 2011 2021 one X = Fragmented - 6 LSOAs fragmented/redesigned 2011 2021

text: "Extent" proportion local population live areas classified among deprived higher geography. calculation extent taken IMD technical report Appendix N:

title: Calculate the 'extent' scores when aggregating up small areas — calculate_extent
code: calculate_extent(   data,   var,   higher_level_geography,   population,   weight_high_scores = TRUE )

title: Calculate the 'extent' scores when aggregating up small areas — calculate_extent
text: data Data frame containing variable aggregated, lower level geography population estimates, higher level geographical grouping variable var Name variable data frame containing variable aggregated (e.g., score) lower level geography higher_level_geography Name variable data frame containing higher level geography names/codes population Name variable data frame containing population estimates lower level geography weight_high_scores TRUE higher scores weighted, else lower scores weighted. indicators like 'Alchol Misuse' 'Ambulance Wait Time' set TRUE. higher values outcomes indicate worse outcomes (higher vulnerability lower capacity) weighting focused. indicators like 'Physical Activity' 'Bed Availability' set FALSE. lower values outcomes indicate worse outcomes (higher vulnerability lower capacity) weighting focused.

title: Calculate the 'extent' scores when aggregating up small areas — calculate_extent
text: "population living deprived 11 30 per cent Lower-layer Super Output Areas receive sliding weight, ranging 0.95 deprived eleventh percentile, 0.05 deprived thirtieth percentile. practice means weight starts 0.95 deprived eleventh percentile, decreases (0.95-0.05)/19 subsequent nineteen percentiles reaches 0.05 deprived thirtieth percentile, zero areas outside deprived 30 per cent" direction scale data inputted functioin always matches data outputted. example data inputted function high scores equals high vulnerability, outputted data set hold relationship true.
